wikipedia_page.main: Helen Fry (born 1967) is a British historian, lecturer and biographer, with especial reference to the Second World War.

response: Ramcke was returned to Europe in March 1946. After a brief period in Belgium, he was transferred to the London Cage.Mallett 2013, p. 174 Historian Helen Fry has written that he was considered at this time to be a "bombastic nasty man who sought to blame others for the crimes of the regime". During his interrogation at the London Cage Ramcke retracted claims that New Zealand soldiers, including Māori personnel, had committed atrocities during the fighting on Crete which were contained in the book of memoirs he had written while in American custody.Fry 2017, p. 119 Ramcke was later transferred to a camp at Lüneburg and gave evidence in Student's war crimes trial. He was greatly angered when Student was convicted.
Helen Frye or Fry may refer to:
*Helen Frye (writer), British writer and poet, see 1970 in literature
*Helen Fry, a song on The Felice Brothers (album)

Since 2010 Smith, while continuing to be closely involved with classical studies and especially Diogenes of Oinoanda, has also established a considerable reputation for his highly original research and writing on a variety of 20th-century figures. These include the writers Rose Macaulay,M. F. Smith, Dearest Jean: Rose Macaulay’s Letters to a Cousin, Manchester University Press, Manchester, 2011. Virginia Woolf,Articles in English Studies 92 (2011), 55–83; 95 (2014), 538–556; 97 (2016), 277–297. Dorothy L. Sayers,"Dorothy L. Sayers and the Somersham Pageant of 1908", Seven: An Anglo-American Literary Review 28 (2011), 79–96. and Katharine Tynan,“Letters from Rose Macaulay to Katharine Tynan", English Studies 99 (2018), 517–537. the artists Helen and Roger Fry"'New' Portraits by Roger Fry (1866–1934) of Helen Fry and Vanessa Bell", The British Art Journal 17, no. 3 (Spring 2017), 34–39; "A Complete Strip-off: A BloomsburyThreesome in the Nude at Studland", The British Art Journal 20, no. 2 (Autumn 2019), 72–77. and Tristram Hillier,"The First Visit of Tristram Hillier (1905–1983) to Portugal", The British Art Journal 20, no. 1 (Spring/Summer 2019), 90–97. the art critic Clive Bell,"Clive Bell's Memoir of Annie Raven-Hill", English Studies 100 (2019), 823–854; "A Complete Strip-off: A Bloomsbury Threesome in the Nude at Studland", The British Art Journal 20, no. 2 (Autumn 2019), 72–77. the trade unionist and social reformer Madeleine Symons,Madeleine Symons: Social and Penal Reformer, Bristol: SilverWood Books, 2017. and Richard Williams Reynolds, schoolteacher of J. R. R. Tolkien.“The British Connection: The Secret Son of Brig.-Gen. Daniel Harris Reynolds", Arkansas Historical Quarterly 76, no. 2 (Summer 2017), 144–176.
* "'New' Portraits by Roger Fry (1866–1934) of Helen Fry and Vanessa Bell", The British Art Journal 17, no. 3 (Spring 2017), 34–39.
